Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Phylogeny and Floral Evolution of Malpighiaceae
Award.AbstractNarration:
Malpighiaceae is a large, ancestrally New World flowering plant family that has dispersed independently to the Old World on seven separate occasions during the past ~60 Myr. The distinctive floral morphology of New World species includes oil glands, which provide pollinators with rewards other than pollen or nectar. The flowers that produce nutrient oils also have a unique bilateral floral symmetry that has been conserved for millions of years via interactions with specialist oil-bee pollinators. All Old World species, in contrast, have regular flowers with radial symmetry. This project will investigate diversification in plant-pollinator mutualism within the family by producing a morphological and molecular phylogeny of ~1300 Malpighiaceae species. In addition, the researchers will investigate the early genetic and developmental basis of bilateral symmetry in the New World species and establish the genetic and developmental basis for the convergent evolution of regular flower phenotypes in the Old World species.

This study of this large and ecologically important group of tropical plants will serve as a model to understand whether similar genetic and developmental mechanisms are driving the parallel evolution of flower shape. The project will train a post-doctoral researcher, undergraduate and graduate students, including individuals from under-represented groups. Research results will be disseminated through an online monograph on the Malphigiaceae, and through targeted short-courses for elementary and high school students within Cambridge, MA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Three primary research outcomes are resulting from the project. First, our work promotes thinking of the evolution of floral symmetry development at a previously ignored hierarchical level, which is informative to understand how the developmental process evolves. Through investigating five-petaled flowering plants, we have demonstrated that development indeed constrains the processes that give rise to floral zygomorphy in a specific lineage, while phylogenetic distance allows relaxation of these constraints, which provides novel insights on the role that development plays in the evolution of floral zygomorphy. Second, we have also demonstrated that the origin and evolution of morphological parallelism in Malpighiaceae, especially in the context of pollination-associated shifts of floral symmetry, is always associated with modifications of CYC2-dependent developmental mechanism. However, the way how the CYC2mechanism has been modified is stochastic and contingent. These findings further illustrate a major theme in evo-devo that is organisms share master genes, which govern the morphology and the evolution of the body plan. Parallel shifts in floral forms are the result of the evolution of master genes in response to plant-pollinator mutualism. Third, for the zygomorphic flowers of New World Malpighiaceae, the radial pattern of CYC2expression during the early stage of floral development suggests CYC2’s role in meristem patterning. This broad pattern of CYC2expression is later restricted to solely the dorsal domain of the flower suggests its distinct role in early zygomorphic development compared to other zygomorphic-flowered species, such as snapdragon and legume, where CYC2is maintained in the dorsal domain of floral meristem throughout the development of zygomorphy. This finding begs for further research to reveal the ancestral function of CYC2genes in floral development, which had been the key player for the evolution of one of the most homoplastic traits in plants. Overall, our studies highlight the need to employ evolutionary developmental approaches within the context of an explicit phylogenetic framework. While carrying out these projects at Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU), PI Zhang advised one post-doctoral researcher and one graduate student and trained four undergraduate students in their senior research, who learned molecular lab techniques and bioinformatics analyses. The research experiences they gained helped them for their academic and career pursuits. Among the undergraduates, one later joined Zhang lab to obtain her M.S. degree and now is applying for Ph.D. programs, one is an M.S. candidate of crop and soil environmental sciences at Virginia Tech, while the other two pursued careers in medicine. The researchers, including the undergraduate, graduate students, the postdoc, and PI Zhang,  presented their discovery at regional, national, and international conferences as while as in the classrooms of undergraduate and high school students. PI Zhang gave multiple seminars for the undergraduate students including the Berglund Seminar Series organized by VCU, the departmental seminars at various undergraduate oriented colleges, such as James Madison University, Virginia State University, William and Mary, and Zhejiang University (China). Zhang also took an opportunity to highlight her research and engage in meaningful conversations about biological evolution with high school students in AP Biology class at Thomas Dale High School in Chester, Virginia.
